position.marginalia_text: Quinctiliani, Pontaniq[ue] Liuius: item ipsius Theodosij, Machiauelli, et complurium Politicorum. Vt Corn. Tacitus imperatoris Taciti, Lipsij, et multorum Pontificum. Duo singulares in sua vena historici. (

marginalia.translation: The Livy of Quintilian and Pontanus; further of Theodosius himself, of Machiavelli and of several politicians. Just like the Cornelius Tacitus of the commander Tacitus, of Lipsius and of many priests. These are two remarkable historians in their own vein.

position.marginalia_text: Populus, vt vnum corpus, plurimum potest: per singula corpora vilescit. Senatus, vt vnum Concilium, auctoritate pra[e]pollet: in singulis personis, illustrem pra[e] se fert dignitatem. Populus sophisticè pra[e]fertur: Senatus energeticè pra[e]ponitur. Ibi potestas sine opibus: hîc opes non sine potestate. Alterius apparens maiestas: alterius vera. Idiota[e] titulo capiuntur: Senatores Rempublicam capessunt; prouincias administrant; res ciuiles, bellicasq[ue] procurant; rerum propriaru[m], communiumq[ue] potiuntur. Bellissimè, quotiès opus, demulcentur simplices: rident in sinu hypocrita[e]. Quod semel hîc pra[e]libatum, sa[e]piùs deinceps obseruandum. Quicquid pra[e]texitur, omnia tandem Magnoru[m]. Interim libet speciosa vtrinq[ue] argumenta, liberis, sed a[e]quis ponderibus examinare.

marginalia.translation: As one body, the people is most powerful; by individual bodies it becomes worthless. As one council, the senate is superior in authority; in individual persons, it exhibits a distinguished dignity. The people are cleverly held in higher esteem, the senate is actively put in charge. In the former there is power without resources, in the latter there are resources and power. That of the one is visible authority, that of the other true authority. Laymen are captivated by a title, senators take hold of the Republic, rule provinces, attend to civic and military business, take possession of private and collective matters. Whenever necessary, the simple people are soothed in the nicest way - the pretenders laugh to themselves. What is offered here as a first tasting, must be studied more often later. Whatever way it is packaged, in the end everything belongs to the Magnates. Meanwhile, I would like to examine the fine-sounding arguments on both sides with frank but fair criteria.
